gov.nih.nlm.meme.client
Class ChangeDataSourceAction

java.lang.Object
  javax.swing.AbstractAction
      gov.nih.nlm.meme.client.ChangeDataSourceAction
All Implemented Interfaces:
Action, ActionListener, Cloneable, EventListener, Serializable
public class ChangeDataSourceAction
extends AbstractAction

Used for GUI buttons or menu items allowing the user to switch databases. Use of this class is not trivial. You will want to create an instance of the action which is relative to a particular Component (for when the dialog opens up). The initial data source selection is specified in the constructor. Once the action exists, you should connect any interested listeners to it, as they will be informed of any change to the server information via a DataSourceChangeEvent. Additionally, any GUIs that should be disabled while the new data source connection is being validated should respond to the other DataSourceChangeListener methods which indicate when the frame should be disabled and when it should be re-enabled. For a full test-example please see TestFinderFrame.

Author:
Brian Carlsen (bcarlsen@apelon.com)
See Also:

Method Detail

actionPerformed

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e)
Opens a dialog that allows the user to select a data source to use. The list of choices is obtained through the MIDServices.

Parameters:
e - a dummy event

Remove a listener.

fireDataSourceChanged

protected void fireDataSourceChanged(String new_service)
Inform listeners that the data source has changed via a DataSourceChangeEvent.

Parameters:
new_service - the new mid service value

fireEnableGlassPane

protected void fireEnableGlassPane()
Inform any GUI component listeners that they should be re-enabled. This method is called once the new data source selection is validated.

fireDisableGlassPane

protected void fireDisableGlassPane()
Inform any GUI component listeners that they should disable themselves. This method is called before the new data source is validated in order to allow applications to gracefully disable their frames (i.e. put up an hourglass cursor and prevent user interaction).
